sections.text:
The adaptive immune response eliminates infected and cancer cells through the recognition of antigenic 11
peptides displayed by major compatibility complex class I (MHC-I) molecules1,2. A single transporter, the 12
transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP), supplies nearly the entire peptide repertoire for the 13
many MHC-I alleles3–5. A fundamental unresolved question is how TAP transports peptides with vast se-14
quence diversity. Here, using cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), we determined seven structures of hu-15
man TAP in the presence and absence of peptides with different sequences and lengths. We observe 16
that peptides are suspended in the transmembrane cavity of TAP with the peptide N- and C-termini an-17
chored at two distal binding pockets. The central residues of the peptide are unrestricted, making few 18
contacts with TAP. A minimum of eight residues is required to bridge the two binding pockets, aligning with 19
the lower length limit for MHC-I binding6,7. Mutations in TAP that disrupt hydrogen bonds with the peptide 20
termini nearly abolish MHC-I surface expression, indicating that binding depends on interactions with 21
mainchain atoms at the two termini. By utilizing two spatially separated binding pockets and concentrating 22
interactions at the two ends of the peptide, TAP functions as a molecular caliper, selecting peptides for 23
length while permitting sequence diversity. 24
25
Introduction 26
27
Cytotoxic T cells recognize and eliminate diseased cells upon the detection of foreign peptides displayed 28
by cell surface MHC-I molecules. The loading of intracellular peptide antigens onto MHC-I molecules oc-29
curs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and involves several key steps1. In the cytosol, proteins are de-30
graded into small peptides by the proteasome8,9. A small fraction of these peptides is transported into the 31
ER by the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP)10–13. There, high affinity peptides are se-32
lectively loaded onto MHC-I by the peptide loading complex and eventually displayed on the surface of 33
the cell for immunosurveillance2,14. Peptides derived from endogenous proteins are immunologically silent 34
due to self-tolerance. In the context of viral infection or malignant transformation, however, displayed pep-35
tides derived from foreign or aberrant proteins trigger an immune response that eradicates the diseased 36
cell. 37
38
The potential sequence space of foreign peptides is vast, due to the combined diversity of viral proteomes 39
and products of mutational burden in malignant transformation. Display of these peptides thus depends 40
on antigen presentation machinery flexible enough to accommodate broad sequence diversity. The princi-41
ples governing MHC-I presentation are well understood6,15,16. Humans have three classical MHC-I (HLA-42
A,B,C) genes that are highly polymorphic, resulting in vast genetic diversity within a population. Further-43
more, by interacting with the peptide’s backbone and a few anchoring residues, each MHC-I allele can 44
present a unique cohort of peptides. In contrast, our understanding of how TAP accommodates vast se-45
quence diversity remains incomplete. Each of us only possesses one TAP, which exhibits very limited de-46
grees of polymorphism17–21. One might expect TAP to be promiscuous as this transporter provides pep-47
tides to the many MHC-I alleles. However, numerous studies showed that TAP does exercise a certain 48
degree of substrate preference. TAP most efficiently transports peptides of 8-12 residues in length, a size 49
similar to the peptides MHC-I molecules bind22,23. Although the upper size limit is not clearly established, it 50
is widely accepted that the lower limit is 8 residues22,24–26. Also, like MHC-I, free N- and C- termini of the 51
peptide are essential for TAP binding. Modification at either terminus reduces peptide recognition sub-52
stantially27–30. Finally, the sequence tolerance of TAP seems to be broad. It appears that only the N-53
terminal three positions and the C-terminus determine binding affinity26,29,31,32. Previous studies have 54
shown that the peptide is bound in an extended conformation33 and that specific residues on TAP influ-55
ence substrate binding34–39. However, molecular details of the TAP-peptide interaction are necessary to 56
understand the functional properties of TAP. 57
58
In this study, we used cryo-EM to determine a series of structures of human TAP, both in the absence of 59
peptide and in the presence of peptides with various sequences and lengths. These findings define the 60
molecular basis of how TAP selects peptides of the appropriate length with vast sequence diversity for 61
MHC-I presentation. 62
63
Results 64
65 66 The structures of TAP in the presence and absence of peptide substrates 67 68
Wild-type (WT) human TAP was overexpressed and purified from human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells in 69
the detergent glycol-diosgenin (GDN) (Extended Fig. 1a) for biochemical and structural studies. TAP is a 70
heterodimeric, ATP binding cassette (ABC) transporter consisting of two polypeptide chains, TAP1 and 71
TAP2 (Fig. 1a). Each subunit has three structural domains: an N-terminal transmembrane domain (TMD0) 72
that interacts with other components of the larger peptide loading complex, a six transmembrane helical 73
domain (TMD) that forms the translocation pathway, and a nucleotide binding domain (NBD) that hydro-74
lyzes ATP (Fig. 1a). The TMD0 domains facilitate MHC-I loading, but are not essential for TAP peptide 75
transport activity40,41. The biochemical properties of the recombinant protein were assayed in the pres-76
ence or absence of a 9-mer peptide containing residues RRYQKSTEL. This peptide has been well-char-77
acterized as a substrate transported via TAP29 and presented on the cell surface by HLA-B2742. Thus, it is 78
designated as the b27 peptide in this work. In the absence of peptide, TAP hydrolyzes ATP at a specific 79
turnover rate of 2 per min (Fig. 1b,c). The b27 peptide stimulates ATP hydrolysis in a dose-dependent 80
manner (Fig. 1b) and, consistent with previous studies27–30, stimulation is abolished by blocking either the 81
free amino- or the carboxyl-termini (Fig. 1c). 82
Using cryo-EM, we determined seven structures of TAP in the absence and presence of peptides ranging 83
from 7 to 14 residues long (Fig. 1d,e, and Extended Fig. 1-3). All structures were determined in the ab-84
sence of ATP, as previous work showed that ATP reduces the affinity of peptides for TAP43. The highest 85
quality maps were obtained with 9-mer peptides, followed by the apo, 8-mer, and 14-mer bound struc-86
tures. Although the flexibility of the TAP1 NBD impacted the overall resolution, the densities for the TMDs 87
and the bound peptides are well defined, permitting unambiguous assignment of the molecular interac-88
tions between TAP and the corresponding peptide substrate (Fig. 1e, 2a, and Extended Fig 3). In the 89
presence of the 7-mer peptide, which is shorter than the preferred minimum length for TAP, the structure 90
exhibits greater heterogeneity, limiting the resolution to 5.1 Å (Extended Fig 1c). In all reconstructions, 91
amorphous densities corresponding to the TMD0 domains are visible only at a lower contour, indicating 92
that the TMD0 of both TAP subunits are flexible. 93
94
Globally, all the structures exhibit a similar NBD-separated conformation with the peptide-translocation 95
pathway open to the cytoplasm (Fig. 1e). The largest degree of NBD separation is observed in the ab-96
sence of peptide where the two ATP-binding sites are 53 Å apart. In the presence of peptides, the two 97
halves of TAP move closer towards each other; the most significant change occurs with the 8-mer peptide 98
(26 Å narrower), and the least change is associated with the 14-mer peptide (18 Å narrower). 99
100
Two different configurations of the TMDs are observed among the seven structures (Extended Fig. 4). 101
Five structures exhibit a typical inward-facing conformation where the translocation pathway is fully 102
sealed at the ER luminal side (Extended Fig. 4a). However, the structures obtained with the b27 (9-mer) 103
and b27" (7-mer) peptides deviate from this configuration (Extended Fig. 4b-c). Instead, they both display 104
a lateral opening that connects the translocation pathway to the membrane. The gap between the TM hel-105
ices is filled with lipid molecules, blocking peptide access to the ER lumen (Extended Fig. 4b,d). The oc-106
currence of this lateral opening does not seem to be correlated with the length or sequence of the bound 107
peptide. Furthermore, a similar lateral opening was previously observed in the structure of TAP stabilized 108
by the viral inhibitor ICP4744,45. Whether this opening is an intrinsic step in the peptide transport cycle or 109
merely a reflection of structural flexibility in the absence of other members of the peptide loading complex 110
remains a subject for future investigation. 111
112 113 The 9-mer peptides bind in extended conformations parallel to the membrane 114 115 116 To understand how TAP recognizes peptide antigens, we first analyzed the structures of TAP in complex 117
with three 9-mer peptides (Fig. 2), which are optimal in length for binding22,23. These peptides, IL-118
KEPVHGV (a2), RRYQKSTEL (b27), and QYDDAVYKL(c4), are natural products of the antigen pro-119
cessing pathway being presented by the three representative MHC-I alleles, HLA-A246, HLA-B2742, and 120
HLA-C447, respectively. 121
122
The structures of the a2- and c4-bound TAP are essentially identical, evident by the overall root mean 123
square deviation (rmsd) of 0.8 Å. In contrast, the b27-bound structure exhibits a different TMDs configura-124
tion as described (Extended Fig. 4). In all structures, the peptides are situated in a central cavity encir-125
cled by TM 2-6 of both TAP1 and TAP2 (Fig. 2a-b). When viewed from a perspective perpendicular to the 126
membrane plane, each peptide stretches roughly 27 Å across the TM cavity (Fig. 2b). Interactions with 127
TAP are concentrated at the N- and C- terminal ends, primarily involving main chain atoms of the peptide 128
(Fig. 2c-f). Side chains at the first three positions and the last position also variably contact TAP, further 129
enhancing binding in a sequence-dependent manner (Fig 2c-d). The central positions make few contacts, 130
which are exclusively through side chain atoms. 131
132
Despite their sequence diversity, the three 9-mer peptides are stabilized in the peptide binding pocket by 133
a common set of interactions involving backbone atoms on separate ends of the peptide (Fig. 2e-f). 134
These interactions, including eight hydrogen bonds, a cation-p and two van der Waals’ interactions, ena-135
ble sequence-independent binding. Specifically, at the N-terminal region, the free amino group of each 136
peptide forms a cation-p interaction with W308 and two hydrogen bonds with E242 and D246 in TAP1 137
(Fig. 2e-f). The carbonyl oxygen and amide at positions 1 and 3 are coordinated through hydrogen bonds 138
by TAP1 R312 and Y309, respectively. Furthermore, TAP2 L377 forms van der Waals’ interactions with 139
the N-terminus of all three peptides and R373 interacts with the main chain atoms in the a2 and c4 140
peptides but not with the b27 peptide (Fig. 2c-d). In comparison, binding at the C-terminal end of the pep-141
tide is dominated by residues from TAP2 (Fig. 2e,f). The terminal carboxyl group of all three peptides are 142
engaged by TAP2 N269 and R273 via hydrogen bonds, as well as by longer-range electrostatic interac-143
tions with TAP2 R210. The peptide terminal amide bond is stabilized by van der Waal’s interactions with 144
TAP2 L266 and hydrogen bonds with TAP2 R273 and TAP1 Y408. The latter residue, Y408, was previ-145
ously identified to interact with the C-terminal end of peptides in mutagenesis studies18,48. 146
147
All backbone-binding residues on TAP1 and TAP2 are highly conserved among different species (Ex-148
tended Fig. 5). To investigate their functional significance in a cellular context, we analyzed the surface 149
expression of MHC-I molecules in cells carrying different TAP variants (Fig. 2g and Extended Fig. 6a-b). 150
In TAP-knockout (KO) cells, MHC-I surface presentation is severely impaired, consistent with the essen-151
tial role of TAP in providing peptide antigens to complete MHC-I folding. While rescue with wild-type TAP 152
(WT) restores MHC-I surface expression, TAP mutants variably rescue transport depending on the posi-153
tion mutated. Alanine mutations in the N-terminal binding residues, E242, D246, and R273, resulted in the 154
greatest defects in transport with a 50-60% decrease in surface MHC-I level relative to WT. On the other 155
hand, eliminating the hydrogen bond between TAP1 Y309 and the third amide on the peptide resulted in a 156
modest 10% reduction. Mutating R373, which interacts with two out of the three peptides at position 2, 157
had no effect. Most strikingly, combining substitutions at the N- and C-terminal ends reduced MHC-I sur-158
face expression to a level similar to that of the TAP KO cells. Loss of function was not due to reduced ex-159
pression or folding of TAP (Extended Fig. 6c-e). These data indicate that engaging the free amino and 160
carboxyl termini are critical for peptide binding to TAP. This principle holds true in the cellular context, 161
where peptides with variable length and diverse sequences are available for MHC-I presentation. 162
163
The N- and C-terminal binding pockets impose sequence preferences 164
165
Thus far we have shown that TAP binds peptides primarily through interacting with the peptide backbone, 166
independent of its sequence. Nevertheless, earlier studies demonstrated that TAP does exhibit 167
preferences for specific peptide sequences particularly at the N- and C- termini29,31,32,49. Such sequence 168
preferences arise from the structural and electrostatic properties of the peptide-binding site (Fig. 3) 169
170
The amino group of each peptide inserts into a deep pocket (the N-pocket) lined with charged and polar 171
residues from TAP1, including E242, D246, W308, and E301 (Fig. 2d and 3). The strong negatively 172
charged surface of the N-pocket and the narrow gate formed by TAP1 E301 and TAP2 R373 explain why 173
the free amino terminus of the peptide is important for high-affinity binding, why a positively charged 174
amino acid at the first position is preferable29, and why negatively charged and aromatic residues are dis-175
favored26,31 (Fig. 3). 176
177
The C-terminus of the peptide docks into a pocket that differs substantially in size, depth, and electrostatic 178
surface potential from the N-pocket (Fig. 3). The C-pocket can be divided into two regions, a positively 179
charged surface where the terminal carboxyl group binds and a hydrophobic cleft that interacts with the 180
side chain of the C-terminal residue. Previous studies have shown that peptides with a hydrophobic C-181
terminal residue have a higher affinity for TAP in human, mouse, and the rat cimu alleles24,27,28. The rat 182
cima allele is uniquely capable of transporting peptides with a C-terminal basic residue. This functional 183
polymorphism can be attributed to a single amino acid difference in the C-pocket, where all residues are 184
highly conserved except for TAP2 M218 (Extended Fig. 5). In human TAP, M218 lines the hydrophobic 185
region of the C-pocket (Fig. 3, right panels). In the cima allele, this residue is replaced by a glutamate resi-186
due, which is positioned to form ionized hydrogen bond interactions with positively charged side chains at 187
the peptide C-terminus, thus allowing peptides with C-terminal basic residues to be transported. 188
189
A minimum of eight residues are necessary to engage N- and C-pockets concurrently 190
191
Many studies have demonstrated that peptides with fewer than eight amino acids are inefficient in com-192
peting with model peptides or in being translocated into the ER24–26. This length threshold coincides with 193
that of MHC-I molecules, which cannot bind peptides shorter than eight residues7,50,51. To understand the 194
molecular basis of the minimum length requirement, we modified the b27 peptide to generate shorter 195
peptides and analyzed how they differ from the parent 9-mer (Fig. 4). The 8-mer peptide (b27’) was de-196
void of the central lysine at position 5 and the two 7-mer peptides each lack an additional residue on ei-197
ther side of the lysine. Compared with b27, the 8-mer peptide increased the ATPase activity of TAP to a 198
slightly greater extent (Fig. 4a). In contrast, neither 7-mer peptides stimulated ATP hydrolysis, suggesting 199
that the compromised function of the 7-mer peptides is likely attributable to their shorter length rather than 200
their sequences. 201
202
The structure shows that the 8-mer peptide anchors to TAP at the N- and C-termini through the same in-203
teractions as b27 (Fig. 4b and Extended Fig. 7). The overall length of the peptide is shortened by 2 Å, 204
leading to a minor contraction of the translocation pathway (Extended Fig. 7a-b). Intriguingly, the TM heli-205
ces are arranged similarly to those of the a2- and c4-bound structures (Extended Fig. 7a), rather than that 206
of the b27-bound structure (Extended Fig. 7b). Consequently, the lateral opening seen in the b27 9-mer is 207
no longer present, and the ER luminal gate is entirely closed (Extended Fig. 7d). 208
209
In the presence of the 7-mer peptide RRYSTEL (b27”), the conformation of TAP was heterogenous. The 210
final reconstruction, determined at 5 Å resolution, closely resembles that of the b27 9-mer bound confor-211
mation (Extended Fig. 1c, 7e), with a clearly visible lateral opening filled by lipid molecules (Extended Fig. 212
7d). Despite the limited resolution, two distinct densities are apparent within the translocation pathway, 213
each attached to either the N- or C-pockets, respectively (Fig. 4c). The density at the N-pocket is clear 214
enough to model the first six residues of the peptide (Extended Fig. 7f), and the density at the C-pocket 215
can accommodate five residues of the peptide (Extended Fig. 7g). The first three (RRY) and last two resi-216
dues (EL) of the b27'' 7-mer peptide within the N- and C-terminal binding sites, respectively, bind in the 217
same way as the b27 peptide (Fig. 4d). The structures of the remainder of the peptide outside of the ter-218
minal binding sites diverges. These data suggest that at the concentration of the cryo-EM sample (150 219
µM), two 7-mer peptides can bind to TAP at the same time. Alternatively, our reconstruction may repre-220
sent two structures, one with a peptide attached to the N-pocket and the other with a peptide at the C-221
pocket. In either case, the structural analysis indicates that peptides with less than eight residues cannot 222
span the entire translocation pathway to engage both binding pockets, thus explaining their lower affinity 223
for TAP and inefficiency in competing with longer peptides. 224
225
A longer peptide engages both binding pockets while the central positions are flexible 226
227
TAP most efficiently transports peptides 8-12 amino acids in length, but the transport of longer peptides 228
also has been reported23,25,27. To understand how TAP interacts with longer peptides, we determined the 229
structure of TAP in complex with the 14-mer b35 peptide, LPAVVGLSPGEQEY (Fig. 1e, Fig. 5, Extended 230
Fig. 1e). The b35 peptide contains a proline at position 2, which is supposed to render it a poor substrate 231
for TAP52,53. Nevertheless, this peptide is presented on the cell surface by HLA-B35 in a TAP-dependent 232
manner, suggesting that it is processed through the canonical antigen processing pathway54. 233
234
In the presence of the 14-mer peptide, the NBDs are separated at a distance intermediate to that of the 235
apo state and 9-mer peptide bound TAP (Fig. 1e). Densities corresponding to the first four and the last 236
four residues of the peptide are clearly observed, but largely absent for the middle six residues (Fig. 5a). 237
Although the b35 peptide engages both binding pockets, important local differences exist compared to 238
how the 9-mer peptides bind TAP (Fig. 5b-c). Specifically, at the N-terminal end, the presence of proline at 239
the second position results in a different backbone conformation that eliminates the hydrogen bonds with 240
D242, E246 and R312 (Fig. 5b). This structural variation is in line with previous findings that prolines are 241
not well-tolerated at position 229,53. Conversely, the C-terminal end of the b35 peptide makes stronger 242
contacts with TAP compared to the three 9-mer peptides (Fig. 5c). The carboxyl group is situated within 3 243
Å from R210, forming a salt bridge instead of long-range electrostatic interactions. Additionally, instead of 244
a leucine or valine, the last residue in b35 is a tyrosine, which forms a hydrogen bond with TAP2 N262, a 245
residue previously shown to affect substrate selectivity38 (Fig. 5c). This example supports the conclusion 246
from earlier studies that detrimental effects from unfavorable residues can be counterbalanced by favora-247
ble residues in other positions26,52. 248
249
250
Discussion 251
In this study, we show that TAP holds each peptide at its two ends, leaving the central positions sus-252
pended in a large transmembrane cavity. Interactions primarily occur through hydrogen bonds with the 253
backbone atoms of the peptide, although side chains also play a minor role. By concentrating the interac-254
tions to the terminal positions and the peptide main-chain atoms, TAP can bind peptides of wide variability 255
in sequence and size. However, a minimum of eight residues in the fully extended conformation is re-256
quired to bridge the distance between the two binding pockets. Consequently, the lower limit for peptide 257
length is set at eight residues, which aligns with the selection criteria for MHC-I. These principles allow 258
TAP to function as a molecular caliper, selecting peptides of the appropriate length while accommodating 259
vast sequence diversity for MHC-I presentation. 260
261
The structural data are consistent with many previous studies. For example, the peptide preferences ob-262
served in biochemical studies26,29,31,32 can be explained by the configuration of the binding pockets. The 263
distance between the N and C termini of the bound peptide varies in a narrow range between 25-28 Å, 264
comparable to the distances determined by nuclear magnetic resonance and double electron–electron 265
resonance experiments33,55. And finally, many peptide-binding residues, identified through mutagenesis 266
and crosslinking experiments34–39, are either in direct contact or near the bound peptide (Extended Fig. 5). 267
268
Recently, the structure of a lysosomal peptide transporter TAPL has been determined in multiple confor-269
mations48. TAPL exhibits approximately 40% sequence identity with TAP, and has broader substrate se-270
quence and length preferences56,57. Although the density of the peptide was inadequate to define molecu-271
lar interactions, the general position of the bound peptide closely resembles those observed in TAP (Ex-272
tended Fig 8a-c). However, unlike TAP, TAPL is a homodimer lacking two distinct binding pockets that 273
would enforce a specific N- to C-terminal orientation. Thus, it is possible that the cryo-EM density ob-274
served in TAPL reflects a mixture of two orientations of the bound peptide. 275
276
Another ABC transporter, the Thermus thermophilus multidrug-resistance proteins A and B (TmrAB), has 277
been used in several studies as a model system to understand the molecular mechanism of human 278
TAP58,59. TmrAB and TAP share approximately 30% sequence identity. Cryo-EM analysis of TmrAB re-279
vealed density in the transmembrane cavity that was interpreted as the peptide substrate59. Structural su-280
perposition indicates that this density is proximal to but separate from the peptides bound to TAP (Ex-281
tended Fig. 8d-f), indicating that TmrAB interacts with its substrate through a mechanism distinct from that 282
of TAP. 283
284
Four of the peptides used in this study have also been co-crystallized with MHC-I42,46,47,54, providing an 285
opportunity to compare directly their recognition by TAP and MHC-I. Peptides bind to MHC-I in a groove 286
between two a-helices atop a b-sheet. Like TAP, the interactions primarily occur at the two ends of the 287
peptide, involving main chain atoms of the bound peptide. Also similar to TAP, the binding sites in MHC-I 288
for the peptide’s free N- and C-termini are ~25 Å apart, thereby imposing a minimum size limit of 8 resi-289
dues for the bound peptide. The major difference from TAP is the involvement of the peptide side chains. 290
MHC-I makes extensive interactions with the side chains of the bound peptide. Certain positions serve as 291
anchors by burying their side chains deep inside binding pockets specific for a particular MHC-I allele. 292
Thus, side chain interactions not only contribute to overall affinity but also dictate allele-specific selectivity 293
in peptide binding60–63. In contrast, TAP does not utilize any specific anchoring residues. Favorable side 294
chain interactions can enhance peptide affinity, but unlike MHC-I, they are not essential for binding. 295
296
The common and unique structural features of TAP and MHC-I correlate with their functional properties. 297
Given the challenge of achieving both high affinity and promiscuity simultaneously, TAP has evolved to be 298
promiscuous, accommodating greater sequence diversity, while the affinities for peptides can vary over a 299
wide range26,29. In contrast, an individual MHC-I molecule prioritizes affinity to prevent dissociation of the 300
peptide on the cell surface. The diversity of peptide presentation is addressed through genetic polymor-301
phism to ensure protection at the population level. Through this delicate balance, TAP provides a com-302
prehensive peptide reservoir for the numerous MHC-I alleles, while each MHC-I binds a peptide with high 303
affinity to ensure immune fidelity. Such a coordinated mechanism enables us to anticipate peptide anti-304
gens from an unpredictable and highly variable pathogenic landscape. 305

Table 1. 541 542 Image processing 543 544 A similar strategy was employed for cryo-EM data processing for all datasets and a representative 545 flowchart is presented in Extended Fig. 2. Super-resolution image stacks were gain-normalized, binned 546 by 2, and corrected for beam-induced motion using MotionCor23. Contrast transfer functions parameters 547 were estimated using CTFFIND44. Subsequent data processing for all the datasets followed a similar 548 procedure. In general, particles were auto-picked from the motion-corrected micrographs with crYOLO 549 using its general model5, extracted in RELION6, and imported into cryoSPARC7. The picked particles were 550 subjected to multiple rounds of 2D classification, and the resulting particles were subjected to ab initio 551 reconstruction with three classes. One class resembled an empty micelle while the other two classes 552 resembled TAP, but with varying continuous density for one of the NBDs. Non-uniform refinement of the 553 best class with the most complete density for the NBDs resulted in a medium-resolution reconstruction of 554 TAP with well-resolved transmembrane helices and NBD2, but with an invisible NBD1. To improve the 555 density of NBD1, all the particles from 2D classification were subjected to iterative rounds of 556 heterogenous refinement using the best reconstruction and a decoy reconstruction with a disordered 557 NBD1 as input models. The resulting particles that gave reconstructions with a complete NBD1 were then 558 subjected to tandem non-uniform refinement followed by local refinement with a protein mask excluding 559 the micelle. These particles were imported into Relion using the csparc2star.py script8 and subjected to 560 Bayesian particle polishing9 and refined again in cryoSPARC. FSC curves were generated in cryoSPARC, 561 and resolutions were reported based on the 0.143 criterion. Masking and B-factor sharpening were 562 determined automatically in cryoSPARC during refinement. 563 564 Model building and refinement 565 566 The sharpened and unsharpened maps from local refinement were used for model building. The initial 567 model was obtained by docking individual domains of the published structure of ICP47-inhibited 568 TAP1/TAP210 into the cryo-EM maps using UCSF ChimeraX11. Models were then manually adjusted using 569 Coot where necessary. The models were then iteratively edited and refined in Coot12, ISOLDE13, and 570 PHENIX14. Regions with poor density were removed such as the TMD0 domains or modeled as 571 polyalanine such as the TAP1 NBD. In the case of the TAP2 NBD, a polyalanine homology model based 572 on the crystal structure of mouse TAP1 NBD was first rigid body fit into the density using ChimeraX, 573 manually inspected, and adjusted where necessary. Then, side chains were manually added and refined 574 in Coot. Residues 632-654 and 660-666 in the TAP2 NBDs were modeled as polyalanine. The quality of 575 the final models were evaluated by MolProbity15. Refinement statistics are summarized in Extended Data 576
